BC-COCAINE-TUNNEL-AZR 
U.S. AGENTS SHUT DOWN BORDER TUNNEL IN COCAINE SMUGGLING PROBE 

   (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)  
 By PAT FLANNERY  
 c.1999 The Arizona Republic  

   NACO, Ariz. _ A border tunnel apparently used to smuggle
hundreds of pounds of cocaine into the United States was slammed
shut by federal agents Tuesday after dawn raids at eight locations
throughout southern Arizona.

   The raids came in the wake of federal indictments charging 13
people with cocaine trafficking and conspiracy, U.S. Attorney Jose
de Jesus Rivera said.

   The indicted, nine of whom were arrested Tuesday, were described
by Rivera as key players in a ring that transported drugs _ mostly
cocaine _ through the tunnel for various Mexican drug cartels.

   The 4-foot-high tunnel traveled for roughly 40 yards on the
Arizona side of the border, leading to a vacant blue and white
house trailer along the border road in Naco.

   Guadalupe Gonzalez, special agent in charge of the FBI in
Arizona, said an elite unit of the Mexican attorney general's
office was sent from Mexico City to serve search warrants at a
Mexican house only yards from the border where the tunnel is
thought to start. The house was searched Tuesday evening, but no
additional arrests were made.

   The Naco tunnel is the fifth found in Arizona in the 1990s.
Three have been uncovered in Nogales _ two of those in January _
and one was found in Douglas in 1990.

   ``If I were a betting man, I'd say there are probably quite a
few more,'' conceded Thomas Raffanello, special agent in charge of
the Drug Enforcement Administration for Arizona.

   Raffanello speculated that some tunnels probably have existed
for years, concealing past smugglers who moved everything from
Chinese immigrants to liquor into this country. It might also have
been used to send drug profits south into Mexico.

   Like many border regions, southeastern Arizona has a history of
immigrant and drug smuggling dating back decades. Recently, the
problem has become acute as other parts of the border in Arizona,
Texas and California are clamped tighter with extra agents and
smuggling detection technology.

   While some Naco residents said Tuesday that they were unaware of
significant drug trafficking in town, border law enforcement
agencies have long noted a rise in drug smuggling in and around the
small, dusty village that straddles the border south of Bisbee.

   Some smugglers drive drugs across in cars. Others backpack it
across the desert, or lead horse trains laden with bales of
marijuana.

   Ron Sanders, chief of the Border Patrol's Tucson sector, also
said his agents ``have been shot at in that area, and been rocked
in that area.''

   The Naco tunnel is not as sophisticated as the nearby Douglas
tunnel, whose entrance in Mexico was under a hydraulically lifted
pool table in a home owned by a reputed drug kingpin. That tunnel
also had a rail inside to help haul dope, and ended inside a
Douglas warehouse.

   Gonzalez said the Naco version is about 5 feet wide and has a
dirt floor. It is shored up throughout by timbers and has lighting
strung along the ceiling, giving it the feel of a mine shaft. It
starts in the Mexican residence and ends underneath the raised
floor of the vacant trailer. Authorities have not disclosed the
owner of the Mexican property.

   Investigators began suspecting a tunnel in the area in December
1996 when a task force seized 5{ tons of cocaine in a Tucson
warehouse. Since then, the probe resulted in the seizure of an
additional 2,668 pounds of cocaine and $1.5 million in cash.

   Nonetheless, Raffanello said, agents ``had no physical proof
that a tunnel existed'' until it was unearthed Tuesday. Though the
trailer and other homes have been under surveillance off and on for
months, the tunnel had never actually been seen.

   On Tuesday, agents dug underneath the trailer to find a wooden
hatch under about 6 inches of dirt. The hatch covered an opening
roughly 9 feet above the floor of the tunnel.

   The tunnel heads directly south under the huge border fence
dividing Naco, Arizona, from its counterpart of the same name in
the Mexican state of Sonora.

   Dick Peacock, who lives next door to the tunnel, said the
trailer at 2107 W. Hogan St. had been vacant for several years.
Nonetheless, law enforcement officials who placed the trailer under
surveillance believe loads of drugs were moved through the tunnel
and into vehicles parked at the trailer in the dead of night.

   Peacock, a retiree who has lived in the trailer next door for 10
years, said he felt ``stupid. I didn't know anything was going
on.''

   The first Peacock knew of local drug activities came about 6
a.m. Tuesday when two U.S. Customs helicopters and a state
Department of Public Safety chopper broke the morning silence.

   The helicopters churned overhead as members of local, state and
federal SWAT teams began their assaults on various locations where
suspects were believed to be living.

   Agents zeroed in on the trailer as well as two other Naco
residences. Search warrants also were served in Tucson, Sierra
Vista and Bisbee.

   Each of the locations was guarded by some of the three dozen
heavily armed FBI, DEA, Border Patrol and Customs agents who took
part.

   Residents near the tunnel entrance were shooed out of the area
for several hours as bomb detection experts and drug-sniffing dogs
inspected the property.
